themes.title: The Significance of Green in Ceramics
points: Green enamel was a major innovation in Qing dynasty porcelain, adding brilliance to the wucai palette and becoming highly prized at the imperial court in Beijing.
Famille verte ceramics, characterized by green and yellow designs, gained popularity in Europe during the 17th century, showcasing cross-cultural appreciation of Chinese artistry.
Celadon, with its olive-green glaze, was valued in China for its jade-like appearance and exported widely to Korea, Japan, Southeast Asia, and the Islamic world.

themes.title: Techniques and Materials in Ceramic Production
points: Qing dynasty porcelain incorporated translucent green enamel, revealing the white porcelain body beneath for contrast, as seen in the bowl with horses and swirling waves.
Korean eumgak cheongja (‘incised celadon') involved carving intricate designs like parrots into the clay before glazing, showcasing technical precision.
Qingbai wares achieved their icy blue-green tinge through iron-infused glazes fired in oxygen-deprived atmospheres, demonstrating early experimentation with chemical reactions in ceramics.

themes.title: Cultural Exchange Through Ceramics
points: Chinese celadon influenced Korean potters during the Goryeo dynasty, who adapted the style to create their own distinct traditions admired for their clarity and jade-like radiance.
Sawankhalok celadon wares from Thailand were exported across Southeast Asia and used in local rituals, highlighting the regional adaptation of Chinese ceramic techniques.
Japanese tea ceremonies during the Kamakura period favored Chinese celadon for its elegance, reflecting the cultural exchange and appreciation of ‘karamono' (‘Chinese things').

themes.title: Symbolism and Decoration in Ceramics
points: The Qing dynasty bowl features auspicious emblems and horses, symbolizing good fortune and power, set against a green wave background for dynamic visual storytelling.
Sawankhalok miniature objects, often used in rituals, were decorated with crackled olive-green glazes, symbolizing natural textures and spiritual significance.
Scrolling floral patterns on Song dynasty qingbai wares mirrored contemporary designs in metalwork and lacquer, connecting ceramics to broader artistic traditions.

themes.title: Hands-On Engagement Ideas
points: Ask students to identify the symbolism in the designs, such as horses or parrots, and discuss their meanings in historical contexts.
Encourage students to compare the green hues across different ceramics and hypothesize how firing techniques influenced the final colors.
Invite students to imagine themselves as collectors or traders in the 17th century and discuss which ceramic piece they would choose and why.
